title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" mandates state and local coordination on cybersecurity with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection requiring the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center to assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections related to cybersecurity risks. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center to assist State and local governments in identifying information system vulnerabilities and security protections. This includes providing tools, resources, and guidelines related to information security through a web portal in consultation with State and local governments. The National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center will provide tools, resources, and training to State and local governments to ensure effective implementation of information security measures. The National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center will provide operational and technical cybersecurity training, privacy and civil liberties training, and assistance to State and local governments to enhance information security measures. The National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center will provide operational and technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security measures, including deploying technology for cyber threat mitigation, analyzing data on information security, and conducting targeted evaluations on government information systems. The National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center will assist State and local governments in conducting targeted operational evaluations, coordinating vulnerability disclosures, and providing information security resources and guidelines. The National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center will assist State and local governments in information security by providing tools, resources, policies, and training on ensuring the security of Federal civilian information systems. Training will include processes consistent with the Department's Fair Information Practice Principles. The Fair Information Practice Principles under the Privacy Act of 1974 aim to limit the use and disclosure of cybersecurity information related to specific individuals, prioritize data integrity, and minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties. The cybersecurity measures aim to safeguard data integrity, minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties, and protect sensitive information from unauthorized access. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security must protect threat indicators and defensive measures, safeguarding proprietary information and ensuring confidentiality. Congressional oversight is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment to ensure constitutional, legal, and privacy protections are observed. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security will provide information on its activities and effectiveness to the House and Senate Committees on Homeland Security. Feedback from State and local governments on the effectiveness of these activities will be included. The House of Representatives passed the information required under this subsection on December 10, 2015. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
